block.p: LEAD: The Collapse of Drexel
LEAD: The Collapse of Drexel
The Collapse of Drexel

Drexel Burnham Lambert began selling its securities and its parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The moves mark the demise of a firm that had come to symbolize the fast-money years on Wall Street. [Page A1.]
It is the end of an era in which speculative debt became Wall Street's stock in trade. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [A1.]

Unlike banks, securities firms are not answerable to any Government agency with the authority to supervise them in their entirety. News Analysis. [D5.] The Federal Reserve and S.E.C. worked to limit damage to the financial markets. [D5.]
Those who have a vested interest in Drexel's fate are scattered across the business landscape. [D5.] Wall Street firms said they had been flooded with calls from Drexel employees. [D4.]
Bankruptcy specialists said Drexel was likely to end up liquidating itself. [D4.]
Markets
Prices of ''junk bonds'' fell sharply but recovered, and trading was volatile all day. [D5.]

Reverberations from the Drexel crisis reached the credit markets, where prices of short-term Treasury securities moved higher and bond prices recorded gains of more than half a point. [D14.] Yields were mixed on C.D.'s and money market accounts. [D14.]
Stock prices closed mixed on sharply higher volume. The Dow Jones industrial average added 4.96 points, to 2,624.10. [D8.]
The price of copper futures surged on New York's Commodity Exchange. [D16.] The dollar was mostly higher. [D16.]
Companies
Chrysler lost $664 million in the fourth quarter and its profits fell 65.8 percent for the year.[D1.]
Forstmann Little and Allen E. Paulson bought Gulfstream Aerospace from Chrysler for $825 million in cash. Mr. Paulson sold Gulfstream to Chrysler in 1985 for $637 million. [D1.]
Bertelsmann is believed to be close to selling its 39 Doubleday Book Shops to Barnes & Noble/B. Dalton. [D1.]
VMS Partners said many of its commercial properties were so troubled that it had no choice but to stop paying certain bills. [D1.]
Integrated Resources filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. [D2.]
Great Northern Nekoosa is putting itself up for sale, the latest step in its attempts to fend off Georgia-Pacific. [D6.]
A Public Service Commission audit found that New York Telephone overpaid the purchasing division of its parent, Nynex. [D20.]
First Executive formally rejected a $6-a-share offer from Rosewood Financial, its largest shareholder. [D6.]
The Economy
After an extensive study of airline competition, the Government concluded that there was no cause for alarm in the shrinking number of major airlines. [D1.]
Retail sales rose a strong 1.6 percent in January, the sharpest gain in more than a year. [D2.]
Technology
Six months behind schedule, McDonnell Douglas began flight tests of the jumbo jet on which its future rides. [D7.]
A computerized shadow-boxing system allows two people to square off without hurting each other. [D7.]
Today's Columns
For President Bush, global warming has become another of the universe's great mysteries. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Former Surgeon General Koop called for a ban on broadcast beer and wine ads. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D18.]
